text: @helenlewis That's partly true, but I don't think it's just due to that. I think both sides have learned from the example of Fox News. And the people who become journalists now are different from those who did a generation ago.

That would imply that people get angrier as they move toward political extremes, and that has been my experience. People on the far right and far left seem to be distinguished less by their joyful adherence to their own doctrines than their hatred of those on the other side.

Headlines in politically neutral publications have almost always been less negative than those in right- or left-leaning ones. So Occam's razor implies that the cause of increased negativity is increased polarization.
Since 2000 headlines in right-leaning publications have always been more negative than those in left-leaning ones, but since 2010 the left has been following the right down. https://t.co/DPPbEOlU00

According to a new study by David Rozado, there has been a big increase in news headlines suggesting fear, anger, disgust, and sadness since 2000, and especially since about 2010. Journalists are pushing your buttons. https://t.co/Sg3QTNbdSz
@erikphoel @EconTalker You could probably create one that could distinguish between Leonardo's paintings and grandma's. The question is how much more precise you could get than that.

The most promising experiment I've seen in doing science better is the Arc Institute. They have enough power, both financial and intellectual, to escape from the gravity well of current scientific practice.

https://t.co/zUDVxgcpG4

We've only explored a small part of the space of how science could be organized and funded. The current default is far from optimal. So there is a lot to be gained by doing better. Michael Nielsen and Kanjun Qiu on "Metascience:" https://t.co/XkeN5r0hah
This is not just a theoretical worry. Good nonprofits, for example, waste a large proportion of their time and energy preparing reports for big (and thus bureaucratic) donors.
More accountability isn't always better. In fact, the better an organization is, the more measuring their performance decreases it.
@amtrpa @ESYudkowsky Ooh, yes, "AI equity" would be the perfect fly paper.
@XiXiDu @ESYudkowsky Good point. Good name too; it sound serious.

@ESYudkowsky Maybe the solution is to invent two separate terms for the two subparts of "AI Safety," not killing people and not being politically incorrect. But they have to sound legit to get adoption; the name for the latter can't be overtly disparaging.
@ESYudkowsky When I first wrote that I put "AI safety" in scare quotes, since in practice it has expanded to mean AI orthodoxy, but I decided not to try to cram two points into one tweet.

Journalists will be eager partners of the established companies in this project. The examples will generate outrage, which yields the most viral type of story, plus lots of opportunities for low-effort but deep sounding moralizing.

Prediction: Established companies will use cherry-picked examples violating broad definitions of AI safety as a way to suppress competition from startups. New technology is always somewhat unreliable, so startups will always be vulnerable to this type of attack.

@robinhanson The source of the confusion is the misleading use of the word "passion." It's really more a figure of speech when used in this context; one is so interested in something that it's like a passion. Plus the word "passion" is pretty vague to begin with. I avoid it.

Where cars are allowed, by default their number will increase to the point where driving is barely tolerable.

Renderings of the future never acknowledge this. Those with cars are always sprinkled with a civilized number of them, like no actual place in the world. https://t.co/YFPdZPDrXj
@GillesJAE Not really, no. People mostly use the word "power" for both, thereby implicitly ignoring the asymmetry.
@GuyZys By example.
"Pouvoir de nuisance" is a French term that seems to mean the power to do damage. It's an interesting concept because, as Xavier points out, it's so distinct from the power to do good.

"In general, nuisance power and usefulness are inversely correlated. He who lives on his nuisance power has no interest in improving his usefulness. He who lives from his usefulness does not feel the need to harm."

— Xavier Faure, translated mostly by Google
@ColinTheMathmo Make sure to say it with a slight accent though.

Something I taught 10 yo: Some of the patterns in the numbers are intrinsic (e.g. the alternation of even and odd) and others are artifacts of our use of base 10 (e.g. multiplying by 10 is trivial), but both enable shortcuts in calculation.
@MickeyShaughnes @mirandadevine Intelligence.
@hapsize I can't even parse that question.
@darrencraine Teach him to check his answers. You need that no matter which method you use.

@jspujji Seeing and using shortcuts is even more important in startups than in arithmetic.
@__anoop No. I'd have been just as annoyed 200 years ago.

It annoys me when teachers require kids to use laborious, prescribed methods to calculate things (and to "show their work" to prove they did) because it teaches kids not to see the patterns that exist in the numbers.

It's not enough merely to claim you're "raising awareness" of something. That's too easy. You have to be able to claim you're increasing support for it. And to do that, you can't be preaching to the choir, because incremental supporters don't currently agree with you.
Merely getting publicity for a cause doesn't automatically translate into generating support for it. If you get publicity for a cause in an obnoxious way, you'll generate opposition to it.

@ClimateEFund Surely Covid vaccines are sufficient evidence that merely being on voters' minds doesn't automatically translate into support.

If you get an issue into voters' minds in the wrong way, e.g. by blocking traffic a la Extinction Rebellion, you turn them *against* your cause.

@paraschopra By asking them why they chose the things they did. When someone has bad taste there will always be a taint of bogusness about their motives. E.g. that they like the things they do because someone spent a lot of money on brand advertising to make them like them.

@ClimateEFund There are many thousands of people doing serious work to end climate change. Make the effort to find out who they are, and fund them, instead of the shallow stuff you currently fund. Here are a couple leads to start with: https://t.co/R0goGqsCK1, https://t.co/uITDexUu3o.
@ClimateEFund Focus on solutions, instead of clumsy PR gestures that not only achieve nothing, but turn the median voter against the cause.

I've been helping 10 yo prepare for some standardized tests he has to take this year. One is in "non-verbal reasoning." I found some example questions online. They're hard, but we've been plowing through them. Today I noticed they're for employment screening for adults.

Waking up 10 yo:

10 yo: Is this waking up?

Jessica: Yes.

10 yo: So my dream's not real?

Me: What were you dreaming?

10 yo: That I was building a Lego Millennium Falcon.
Something I taught 10 yo: You can sometimes learn as much from things done badly as things done well. Sometimes it only becomes clear what's needed when it's missing.
@adayeoyh New? I've never known a hacker who drank a lot of alcohol. Hacking and booze are highly incompatible. Caffeine though...

This is why I never worry when a startup initially describes itself as "x for y." That doesn't automatically make it a derivative idea. Lots of truly new ideas were initially conceived in such terms. Maybe most.
Though to be fair, it can help ease the transition to retain some old stuff. People knew how to make carriages like this, and how to ride in them.

These early railway carriages are a good illustration of how much old stuff gets dragged along into the first versions of new things. At first even the inventors of trains couldn't think of them as more than sequences of linked horse carriages. https://t.co/TV7S0OPBzU

@alexisohanian Testing actual aptitude is extremely hard. There are so few questions you can ask if you don't want the result to be influenced by how much kids have learned, and the more constrained you are in choosing questions, the easier it is to prepare for your tests.

@tartley I find kids like learning tricks for solving math problems, because it feels kind of naughty to ignore the procedures they're taught in school. And yet it's not cheating; in fact it's closer to the way mathematicians think.
@nw3 If they wanted to send that message, the way to do it would be to strike important military targets, not playgrounds.

Incidentally, this is yet another example of how standardized tests meant to measure "aptitude" don't actually do so. He's much better at answering math questions now that I've taught him this technique.

Something I explained to 10 yo: Math questions on standardized tests are often meant to test whether you understand math at a deeper level than just grinding through some procedure you've been taught. So when you get what looks like a hard question, first look for shortcuts.

When a class of customers is slow and bureaucratic, the thing for startups to do is compete with them, not try to build things for them. Unless the source of the slowness is regulation; then startups should think twice.
If your world has lots of early adopters, you'll have lots of startups making things for you, and if it doesn't, you won't.
